comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Even then, the cadets stood during the entire game, which was played on November 29, 1913, at the Polo Grounds, in New York City. Army sank Navy and won the game, 22-9.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Isn't that President Woodrow Wilson (talking to the man in the fur coat)?

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Yes, the President did attend the game that day: www.gvsu.edu/hauenstein/index.cfm?id=A34B5ECF-E063-A4F3-B... NYT story on November 14 said that Wilson's family also would be there: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9407E5D7113CE6... The rumpled flag in the photo must indicate the Presidental box. So now we have to figure out who the guy in fur was -- an autograph hound? or a bodyguard in mufti?

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
This is fascinating:

Dwight D. Eisenhower was a linebacker for Army in the 1912 game (which Army lost, 6-0). If only Ike had stayed around for another year, Wilson could have watched a future President playing ball!

comment.author: 34985608@N03
comment._content: Thanks for spotting President Wilson. We'll add the information to the record when we update.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Alas, in this image President Wilson is not merely spotted, but virtually obliterated by that ancient moisture stain on the glass negative.
